title: Remove all authentication flows and eliminate canister/connection system so the app opens directly

requirements.text: Remove all user-facing authentication and verification flows so users can access the app immediately without any login steps, including: CTR ID, access code, email/password, face authentication, and any Internet Identity sign-in UI.

quotes: Remove all authentications include CTR AND ACCESS CODE AND EMAIL PASSWORD AND FACE AUTHENTICATION USER CAN ACCESS APP DIRECTLY

acceptanceCriteria: No screen, modal, banner, or section prompts the user to enter a CTR ID or access code.
No screen, modal, banner, or section prompts the user to enter email/password.
No face verification UI is shown or required anywhere in the app.
There is no Internet Identity sign-in button or login prompt shown anywhere in the app.
User can open the app in a fresh browser session and immediately see the main app content without interacting with any authentication UI.

requirements.text: Remove any feature gating or conditional navigation that depends on authentication, identity state, CTR connection, access code validation, or connection state, and ensure all primary sections (Stocks & Funds, Withdrawal, Customer Support) are accessible immediately on app load.
acceptanceCriteria: On initial load, the app shows a primary section (not a login/connection/auth screen).
Navigation menu contains only main sections (Stocks & Funds, Withdrawal, Customer Support) and none related to login/connection/auth/verification.
All main sections render and are usable without requiring any identity/CTR/access-code step.

requirements.text: Remove CTR/access-code related validation utilities and any UI logic that depends on them so the app no longer enforces CTR ID allowlists or shared access-code allowlists.

quotes: Remove all authentications include CTR AND ACCESS CODE

acceptanceCriteria: No code path in the UI blocks access based on `validateCtrId` or `validateAccessCode` checks.
No user-facing error messages referencing CTR ID or access code validation appear during normal app usage.

requirements.text: Eliminate the canister/connection configuration system from the end-user experience by removing any connection/config initialization banners, backend reachability banners, offline mode notices, and any connection settings panels from the rendered UI so the app does not present canister configuration as a user task.
acceptanceCriteria: No connection/config/offline/reachability banners or notices are displayed anywhere in the app UI.
There is no visible UI that asks the user to configure or validate a canister ID.

requirements.text: Remove backend-side authorization requirements so all backend methods used by the app work for anonymous callers, and preserve compatibility with the existing frontend actor creation by keeping any previously-exposed initialization method as a no-op if it is still referenced by generated interfaces.
acceptanceCriteria: Backend calls used by the UI (profile, balance, add funds, withdraw, histories, health check) succeed for anonymous principals and do not trap due to authorization/permission checks.

If the frontend still references an access-control initialization method (e.g., `_initializeAccessControlWithSecret`), the backend continues to expose it and it performs no authorization gating (no-op) so the app remains buildable and runnable.
No backend feature requires CTR/access code/email/password/face verification to call core methods.

constraints: Do not modify files under frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.ts, frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.tsx, frontend/src/hooks/useActor.ts, frontend/src/main.tsx, or anything under frontend/src/components/ui (immutable paths).
Keep backend as a single Motoko actor in backend/main.mo; only add a migration if a stable-state upgrade is required.
nonGoals: Adding any new authentication mechanism (including third-party auth).
Adding new product features unrelated to removing authentication and canister/connection UX.
Introducing external databases or off-chain services.
